text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen so in 
the curry chapter of my cookbook I talked about

there being two types of curries the coconut 
base one and a water base one and the coconut

one sort of rich and creamy the water base ones 
are brothy and light well this dish is sort of

an in-between so it's got coconut milk in it but 
it's light enough that I literally drink it like

soup it's so good and we use a combination 
of meat and vegetables that are so popular

it's called gaeng gai fakkiew gaeng is curry gai is 
chicken and fakkiew is winter melon which is this

big thing in front of me here this is something 
that my grandmother makes quite a lot and it's

one of my absolute favorite ways to have a curry 
so let's get started so winter melon if you've

never had it before really doesn't have much 
of a flavor on its own but when you cook it it

absorbs flavor of the things around it really 
well it becomes super soft and delicious now

in Thailand winter melons about the size of a 
butternut squash I have never seen something

so big until I came to Canada it's so big in 
fact that they cut it out and sell with you

in slices like this I have seen like a full one 
and it's this massive like thing it's crazy so

anyhow what I want to do is cut off the peel and 
also the seeds and cut this into the inch cube

all right this is a very simple dumb Panther 
kind of curry I'm going to start out by putting

about half of my coconut milk into this pot here 
and reduce it and I got I brought this coconut

milk all the way from Thailand because it's so 
good my brother who lives in Thailand told me

I found this new coconut milk and it's awesome 
when you have to try it and I tried it and it

brilliant and I love the fact that I can seal it 
again so I don't have to transfer the rest of it

into something else so while that's coming to a 
boil and reducing let's look at the protein so

I've got here some chicken bone-in skin-on chicken 
leg and thigh so this is two legs into thighs and

they're chopped into chunks right through the 
bone and you can find chicken that's cut like

this at Chinese butchers and if not you can also 
use chicken drumettes which has a lot of bones

as well and the reason why I chose this kind of 
chicken is so then I can just use water and the

bones from the chicken will turn that water into 
flavorful chicken stock however if you're going

to use boneless chicken you can totally do that 
just make sure you use a good unsalted chicken

stock instead to maximize your flavor okay all 
right so now that the coconut milk is reduced

and it's super thick now I'm going to add my curry 
paste so I'm using red curry paste and I wanted to

just point out because this brand of curry paste 
comes in a little can like this and it's good for

vegetarians because there's no shrimp paste added 
to it however because we are clearly not making a

vegetarian curry what I would do normally is I 
add like a little pinch of shrimp paste into it

to sort of make up for that I forgot my gym pace 
today so we're going to have a non shrimp a sea

curry for today that's all right and of course 
if you're feeling hardcore and you want to make

your own curry paste I have a video for that so 
I'll put the link right up here so now that the

curry paste thick and you can see the coconut oil 
sort of fizzling away around the edges that means

it's ready so what that is is the curry paste is 
now frying in the coconut oil is developing the

flavor so it's you know basically you want the 
herb from the fight to really cook them bloom

now the time is right but again what am i doing 
I can just pour the whole thing in but uh there

you go sometimes you know you do something in your 
life this makes no sense all right so give this a

quick toss get it all covered in the curry paste 
look at that and now I'm going to add the rest

of my coconut milk and it so happens that this 
model is exactly one cup so that makes it easy

but I'm going to add two more cups of water and so 
it's a pretty high ratio of water to coconut milk

but that's what's going to keep this broth yeah 
I like to call it broth light and Sybil I should

say drinkable because I have been known to drink 
this broth I'm going to season this a little bit

with some fish sauce and also some palm sugar to 
cut all that saltiness so now what I'm going to do

is I'm going to let the chicken simmer and braise 
until it's fork-tender for thirty minutes that's

that's about how long it should take but of course 
you always want to check it with a fork but I'm

also going to add my winter melon right now now 
I know some of you are wondering ways obviously

wouldn't take 30 minutes for these things to cook 
and it doesn't but if you cook winter melon just

until they are done they kind of taste like just 
winter melon and that's not very exciting like

it doesn't pays great but if you give it a long 
time to sit and simmer it will absorb all that

flavor and they become sort of a sponge full of 
curry flavor and they don't actually overcook

very easily so you can let them go for a good 30 
minutes and they'll still hold their shape look

at that smells so good in here right now now about 
five minutes before this was done I threw in some

kaffir lime leaves which I just tore into chunks 
and that just add sort of some citrusy freshness

to help balance out the richness of the curry now 
if you notice there is a lot of oil on here and

this is a combination of the coconut oil that we 
separated and also some chicken fat in Thailand is

completely normal and we just leave it as is but 
if it bothers you you can skim some off I would

skim it all up because you are throwing away some 
of that flavor as well the chicken is now super

tender and the winter melon is fully cooked and 
it's going to be translucent all the way through

but it's still holding its shape right now it's 
just soft and delicious and if you look at the the

actual consistency of the broth look how light and 
thin that is right so it's more like a soup so I'm

going to give it a taste oh oh it's so good are 
so comforting it's like chicken soup taken to the

next level but I will add a little more seasoning 
with some fish sauce and this is always what you

want to do when you make curry you don't add all 
your fish sauce in the beginning because you just

never know it's hard to stick something that's 
too salty this next little bit is completely

optional but I wanted to show you anyway because 
it is done in Thailand and I actually like it I'm

going to add in here some pork blood so this is 
pork blood that's sold in a block you can also

do chicken blood actually I would prefer chicken 
but I can only find pork and it's got a texture of

sort of similar between soft and medium firm tofu 
in fact when I was little out of the grocery store

and I saw this being sold and I was so convinced 
it was chocolate flavored tofu thank goodness I

didn't try it before somebody told me that that's 
not chocolate tofu so I'm just going to add this

to the curry and bring it to a boil it doesn't 
need to be cooked for a long time but you do

want to sort of cook it until it's hot thoroughly 
hot all the way through again this is completely

optional all right that looks good to me and now 
I'm going to finish it off with some Thai basil

whoa this pot is full I'm going to throw this 
off now because I just need the residual heat

to wilt the basil and that is pretty much done now 
you can serve it right now if you've got time to

let it sit for a couple hours or even do this a 
day in advance and the winter melon will be even

more flavorful as it sits and absorb all that 
flavor so good we always have curry with rice

in Thailand and this is how we normally would 
serve this curry as well but it's so light and

brothy as you can see that I am actually going 
to paste it as is straight up and it's a great

curry to put with noodles as well so you can make 
like a curry noodle soup so good oh that's hot but

you can have to go from here oh that's so good I'm 
going to have a little bit of the blood ah what a

comforting dish the seasoning is not so strong so 
you can sort of drink it like soup and that blood

if you haven't had it before but you have liver 
it's got a similar flavor so if you like liver I

think you're going to like it cuz it's got almost 
like a a jello ecoboost texture what a great dish

super simple really rustic something you can whip 
up the day before and I can guarantee you you can

eat this for a week and you won't get sick of it 
so the recipe as always we'll be on happy kitchen

calm when you make it send me a photo on Facebook 
Twitter or Instagram and if you haven't subscribed

to the show please do so you never miss an episode 
and I will see you next time for you next time
